newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: South Africa's Mandela said seeking Malaysian oil.
newsitem.headline: South Africa's Mandela said seeking Malaysian oil.

text.p: South African President Nelson Mandela arrived in Malaysia on Thursday on the final leg of a four-nation Southeast Asian tour and is expected to ask Kuala Lumpur for oil.
Mandela, travelling with companion Graca Machel for the first time on a state visit, was received at the airport by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.
In addition to Machel, the widow of former Mozambique president Samora Machel, Mandela has brought with him a 115-member delegation of ministers, officials and businessmen.
South African Minerals and Energy Minister Penuell Maduna said in Singapore earlier on Thursday Pretoria would ask Malaysia to export crude oil.
He said he hoped talks with Malaysia would also open up additional possibilities for investment in South Africa's next oil refinery project.

Malaysia became the fourth-largest investor in South Africa last year -- behind more traditional partners Britain, Germany and the United States -- when the state oil firm Petronas bought 30 percent of listed South African company, Engen Oil.

In a speech at the end of his two-day visit in Singapore on Thursday, Mandela issued a passionate appeal to Asia to see southern Africa as a lucrative place in which to invest and a "geographical anchor" for trade with South America.

"Southern Africa today constitutes one of the most exciting regions of the world; a region endowed with abundant mineral resources, a market of over 100 million people, great tourist potential, democracy and peace," he said.
"This region has the potential to be the geographic anchor of new relations among Asia, Africa and Latin America."
Mandela said he wanted to rebuild cultural and trade ties between two regions he said had been destroyed by European colonisation of Africa.

Mandela urged Asian investors to hurry to South Africa, where economic reforms had opened up "massive mega-projects in mineral processing, petrochemical industries, telecommunications, car manufacturing, tourism, transportation and other infrastructure".

There were "opportunities for large profit margins, the advantage of a sophisticated banking system, the availability of a developed communications network, the freedom to repatriate profits and the advantage of tax holidays in certain designated areas," he said.
Mandela, who has been to the Philippines, Brunei and Singapore on this tour, will meet Mahathir on Friday. They will also witness the signing of several agreements.
Malaysia established diplomatic relations with South Africa in November 1993 after the dismantling of apartheid and has been supportive of Mandela's national unity government.
